results.title: Jenny Watson, painter
results.brief_description:
“Jenny Watson, painter” is an interview Sue Ford conducted with fellow Australian artist Jenny Watson in 1975 at the latter’s studio and home on Punt Road, Richmond. The two artists discuss feminism, art and the relationship between art and life in this insightful interview and document of the time.

Jenny Watson (born 25 October 1951) is a leading Australian artist known for her practice intertwining painting with autobiographical and fictional narratives that interrogate the construction of femininity and self. Drawing from personal histories, punk and feminism, her painting practice has developed a unique style since the 1970s, incorporating fabric, text and collage. She has exhibited extensively in Australia and internationally, and her work is held in the collections of the Museum of Contemporary Art, the National Gallery of Australia and the National Gallery of Victoria.

In this 1975 interview, Watson reflects on the current state of art and the changes brought about by the introduction of video, performance, documentation and body art, highlighting the emergence of the personal or subjective within art practice. She discusses the difficulties facing women working in art such as a domestic situation, motherhood, or not being taken seriously; conversely, she points out the support provided by a community of women.

Watson goes on to discuss the shift towards the personal, figurative and diaristic in her recent work, particularly reflecting on the “Horse” series she created in the early 1970s. Filmed standing in front of her most recent body of work, a series of life-size portraits including one of her then-partner, artist John Nixon (“Yellow Painting: John”, 1974), and one of herself, Watson introduces the formal framework and her exploration of the subjective figure.

The interview is a fascinating insight into the development of an important Australian artist’s practice, as well as a testament to the interwoven personal relationships between artists of the period.

group_siblings.title: Egami

results.title: Out
results.brief_description: Initially following the trajectory of a car which is taking ‘The Girl’ (Celia Ireland), out to a social function, this short film allows the viewer to be privy to the thought processes of what it means to go “out”. The girl ponders issues such as timing, kissing, a no sex policy, being interesting, making an impression, pit stops, and identifying the highlight of the evening. Cast also includes John Polson and Suzy Dougherty.

results.title: Louder than words
results.brief_description: A documentary about contemporary performance poetry featuring the work of Melbourne poets Ania Walwicz, Eric Beach and Jas H. Duke. They perform in their own exuberant, idiosyncratic and sometimes bizarre way a selection of their own works.

results.title: 16mm news camera with Cosmicar zoom lens used by GTV-9
results.brief_description: Model 0. Manufactured by Mitchell Camera Corporation Glendale, California. Complete with added Cosmicar zoom lens 22.5-90mm and wooden tripod. Used by GTV 9.

constellations_primary.name: Princesses, rom-coms and sit-coms
constellations_primary.description: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field, but they were also used by film production companies and on TV shows, with some of those involved going on to define different genres.

results.title_for_label: 16mm news camera with Cosmicar zoom lens used by GTV-9
results.description: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field. Three-legged tripods made from firm materials like steel and wood helped steady the kind of image that was collected in production vans for Cinesound Productions and Movietone News. Designed and manufactured in Los Angeles, this model was an improved design on the earlier Mitchell cameras, which were widely used by film production companies like those at Pagewood Studios in Sydney, Australia. The Mitchell Newsreel Camera was a quieter alternative, making it less invasive on sets and in the field.
description_for_label: Newsreel footage was captured on large, bulky 35mm cameras like the Mitchell Newsreel Camera by operators in the field. Three-legged tripods made from firm materials like steel and wood helped steady the kind of image that was collected in production vans for Cinesound Productions and Movietone News. The Mitchell Newsreel Camera was a quieter alternative, making it less invasive on sets and in the field.

results.title: Just desserts
results.brief_description: This wonderfully sensuous short presents the rites of puberty as a menu of Italian favourites: a young girls first period occurs when she is stomping the grapes; gnocchi is forever to remind her of first having sex with a boy; burnt polenta is the taste of lesbian longing. A lovely remembrance of an Italo-Australian adolescence.

results.title: At sea
results.brief_description: A baby boy dies on the journey from Los Angeles to Australia and is buried at sea. Many years later his mother still grieves for him, painfully and bitterly. Penny Fowler Smith uses highly evocative and sometimes abstract imagery to visual the mother’s emotional narration. At Sea is a cinematic reflection on loss.

results.title: Australia's Best: Music & Images of Australians in the 80's
results.creator_credit: Pom Oliver, South Pacific Films and New South Wales Film Corporation
results.brief_description: A music video documentary showcasing the best of Australia’s popular music in the eighties. Features the music of Split Enz, Australian Crawl, INXS, No Fixed Address, Cold Chisel and Icehouse. Includes interviews with celebrities such as Michael Hutchence, Neil and Tim Finn, James Reyne and Grace Knight.

results.title: Australian super 8 films 1981-1986
results.brief_description: The early 1980s saw an emergence of a Super 8 film culture. The three hour compilation tape features 27 Super 8 films produced by Australian artists between 1981 and 1986. It attempts to be a representative survey of prominent filmmakers, themes and style. A rare and important documentation of a fertile aspect of Australian film and visual arts activities. Curated by Michael Hutak, Super 8 Group Australia.

results.title: Overland with Cobb & Co.
results.brief_description: A journey through the outback by Cobb & Co coach. Cobb & Co have a unique place in Australia’s past. The growth of the company went hand in hand with the development of rural Australia. In many ways it made development possible, providing an essential fast transport system on which the rural areas depended. By 1870 Cobb & Co were harnessing 6,000 horses a day to haul their coaches over 28,000 of track every week.
